This fix will not be needed for future Sawtooth 1.2.1, nor to backport updates to Sawtooth 1.1.x that have the sawtooth-devmode repository fix on 2019-01-08, in file sdk/examples/devmode_rust/src/main.rs to correct the default TCP port for the consensus engine from `5005` to `5050`

The older proxy fix, which works for Ubuntu Xenial (LTS 16), but does not work with recent Ubuntu Bionic (LTS 18) is PR https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/pull/29 . This fix works for both Bionic and Xenial.

@benjamincburns Since this is a pretty substantial change (some previous transactions that were previously invalid are now valid), can you summarize the discussion from RocketChat about why this is the desired behavior, what the pros and cons are, and what use cases this support.
Go formatting issues are now fixed.

@aludvik sure thing. 

To be clear, this change doesn't allow for contract state updates when transaction execution fails. It simply records the transaction execution failure in the transaction receipt format that is appropriate for the transaction family.

Prior to these changes there was no way for a client which submitted its transactions via Seth's RPC interface to determine whether the transaction was executed, and what the result of that execution was.

Via the Ethereum RPC interface, the usual transaction flow looks like this:

1. Client submits a message call transaction to a contract address via either the `eth_sendTransaction` or the `eth_sendRawTransaction` RPC call
2. Server responds with RPC response containing transaction hash in the `result` field
3. Client uses the transaction hash returned by the server to poll for the result of the transaction via `eth_getTransactionReceipt`.
4. Until the transaction is mined into a block, the server always returns `null` in response to the client's `eth_getTransactionReceipt` request.
5. When the transaction is mined into a block, regardless of whether the transaction succeeded or failed,  the server responds to `eth_getTransactionReceipt` with a valid transaction receipt.
6. The client inspects the `status` field in `eth_getTransactionReceipt` to determine whether their transaction succeeded or failed.

If no receipt is produced when a message call to a contract address fails due to a runtime error (e.g. due to the `REVERT` opcode), then the client can't tell the difference between transaction failure, and the transaction never starting.

As to what use-cases this supports, I'm working on integrating the Truffle toolsuite with Sawtooth-Seth. See the blocked tickets on the [commit-referenced Jira issue](https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-1460) for more info.
Looks like I had some rust formatting issues as well - those should be fixed up now.

@benjamincburns Thanks for the response. Am I correct in understanding there are three types of validity with Ethereum transactions? 
1. Totally valid - The transaction "object" was valid and the execution was a success
2. Valid but failed -  The transaction "object" was valid but the execution failed
3. Invalid - The transaction "object" was invalid because of something like a bad signature, bad payload, incorrect nonce.

Is that characterization accurate? Does the nonce still get updated if the transaction execution fails?

Can we find another solution which does not rely on sleep? Not only will this likely wait too long on average, but also if it takes greater than 5 seconds on a slow system, it would fail. Better to find another approach to determining the actual state and then continue.

Added Developer Certificate of Origin (DCO) to https://github.com/CertifiedTrue/ and Signed-off-by” cliveb line in each commit message after-the-PR forced signature to each commit. Unsure why DCO sign-off is missing still.

Hi Clive,

Thanks for the PR! I see you added the signoff in your PR message. However, the DCO actually checks your commit message for the signoff, so you will need to add the signoff on your commit message instead. If the commit in your PR is your most recent commit, you should be able to do this with `git commit --amend --signoff`, and then force push it to your branch.

Also see: [git commit docs](http://schacon.github.io/git/git-commit.html), [sawtooth contributing guide](https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/community/contributing.html)

I'm fine with changing the banner to be Copyright Hyperledger Sawtooth Contributors. As I understand it from the Linux Foundation staff, banners aren't actually copyright indications but are meant to facilitate tracking back to the license when the files are copied outside the project.
It should generally be the original person who initially created the banner who changes it. In this case I'm not concerned so long as we change it from "Hyperledger Foundation" (which isn't a thing) to "Hyperledger Sawtooth Contributors".
@daverodz / @dcmiddle: With #62 merged, is there any reason to keep this PR around or can we close it?
Closing due to inactivity. Feel free to reopen rebased off of master to fix conflicts

very true, we should be able to create an account without passing nonce. to add this functionality i need more time as i am new to this piece of code. this was a quick fix for someone to understand what to do in case segmentation violation happens.

I think we should add support for `SAWTOOTH_HOME` and `SAWTOOTH_KEYS` environment variables to most Sawtooth utilities and services. However this would be better done in the core repositories as a shared feature to use here. For the moment just use `${HOME}/.sawtooth/keys` here.
There is still an issue where the RPC service does not shut down cleanly, but it does not appear to have been caused by these changes.
Amended to remove @nick-drozd, whose contributions were largely renaming for API stabilizations.

@grkvlt Looking at the code it seems to me that seth account import {key-file} {alias} writes a file called {alias}.pem but it doesnt matter what the {key-file} is called. My goal was to make the example commands easy to copy-paste in, so I'd like to avoid the brackets. For clarity I changed the example key file to "key-file.pem"
@dplumb94 are you sure? I'll have another look at the code, i thought there was an issue with the key file being copied wrong that has not been fixed yet...

@grkvlt The example in this PR does function properly. I believe there is some bug affecting keys generated with `sawtooth keygen`. It appears that support for non-`.pem` keys was halfway removed. I was not able to get these keys to import properly even with the same name for the key and alias. Do you know if there is a bug registered for this already?

@dplumb94 it looks like you're right, but there's another issue i forgot about, which is that the RPC server and the container running CLI commands must share the `/root/.sawtooth/keys` directory, so that the PEM files created there by `account import` commands can be read:
- https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/blob/master/rpc/src/accounts.rs#L91-L120

Although, it looks like there is a mismatch in key directory names - see the CLI save function:
- https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/blob/master/cli/src/seth_cli/cli/data.go#L104-L140

That's a bigger change to the instructions, so I'd be happy to do that in a second PR.

Currently we have all the build functionality wrapped up in the docker-compose.yaml file, since running `docker-compose up --build` will automatically build all of the images before starting up containers. Additionally, `docker-compose build` can be used to just build the images without starting containers.

I am wondering if this build script provides any additional functionality?

Thanks!

Good point @dplumb94 - I sort of forgot that `docker-compose build` was a thing. But, I would still really like a way of creating the images that I can use where they aren't constrained by needing to work with the compose file, since eventually I want to be able to build a Sawtooth plus Seth platform that is orchestrated by other tools.

I don't think this does any harm, so why not? Eventually we want to create images using a two stage process anyway, to make them smaller, which would be decoupled from the compose file, so this would be a step towards that.

A multi-stage build approach would only need to change the Dockerfiles to toss out dependencies after the executable has been built. This wouldn't necessitate any changes to the current `docker-compose up --build` workflow

A multi-stage build would involve having to uninstall golang, rustc, cargo and so on after the build, *but* you would _still_ have the previous layers from the dockerfile, so the image would still be huge. This is not the right way to create Docker images. You need a build Dockerfile that creates the executables and caches them somewhere (for core we make .deb files, here we just store the executables in a local build dir in the repo on the host), then _another_ Dockerfile will install the minimal set of required libraries and copy the executables from the host to the image.

Here are the results of three Dockerfiles, `test-1` is just `ubuntu:xenial`, then `test-2` has `golang` installed, finally `test-3` has `golang` installed, then removed. Note the `test-3` is not any smaller:
```
REPOSITORY                 TAG                 IMAGE ID            CREATED             SIZE
test-3                     latest              1184f7b369f5        5 seconds ago       538MB
test-2                     latest              7e37631f018d        18 seconds ago      537MB
test-1                     latest              41d13b186bdc        25 seconds ago      112MB
```
Closing after @dplumb94 suggested moving to multi-stage builds as described in https://blog.alexellis.io/mutli-stage-docker-builds/
